initial_version: Andrey Kurkov (born in [[1961]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,8 +1,35 @@
-'''Andrey Kurkov''' (born in [[1961]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]].
+'''Andrey Kurkov''' (born in [[1961]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]] who writes in Russian.  His father was a test pilot for the [[Soviet Union]] and his mother was a doctor.  He is the author of 13 [[novel | novels]] and of 5 books for children. His work is currently translated into 25 languages including English, Japanese, French, Chinese and Hebrew.  He has also written assorted articles for vaious publications world-wide.
 
-Author of 13 novels and of 5 books for children. Translated into 25 languages including English, Japanese, French, Chinese and Hebrew.
+His books are full of black humour, post-soviet reality and elements of [[surrealism]].  
 
-His books are full of black humour, post-soviet reality and elements of [[surrealism]].
+==Life and Works==
+Kurkov supposedly started writing at the age of seven when after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a [[poem]] about the loneliness of the remaining pet.  He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his Soviet education at the time.
+
+As a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].  However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police.  This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period.  He was assigned a prision guard position in [[Odessa]].  It was during this period that Kurkov managed to write all of his children's stories.
+
+Kurkov's first [[novel]] was published two weeks before the fall of the [[Soviet Union]] and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards self-publishing and distribution.  Borrowing money off of friends to fund his work he managed to publish around 75,000 books independently.  Whilst organising distribtuion around the [[Ukraine]], he would also man stalls on busy streets to sell copies by hand.
+
+Like many successful writers Kurkov had difficulty establishing an initial publishing contract.  He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted in which time he had written almost 8 complete [[novel | novels]]. 
+
+Later in his career he has received further acclaim by being one of the most successful Ukranian authors in the post-Soviet era and featuring highly on European bestseller lists.
+
+It is interesting to note that as a Ukranian writing in Russian, Kurkov has come under criticism from some of his contemporaries for not supporting the blossoming Ukranian literary movement.
+
+==Bibliography==
+Novels:
+*''[[Death and the Penguin]]''
+*''Penguin Lost''
+*''A Matter of Life and Death''
+*''The Case of the General's Thumb''
+*''The World of Mr Big Forehead''
+
+For Children:
+*''The Adventures of Baby Vacuum Cleaner Gosha''
+
+==Links==
+*[http://www.abc.net.au/rn/arts/bwriting/stories/s1461208.htm ABC National Radio - A recent interview]
+*[http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/207/648 The Ukranian Observer: ''Andrey Kurkov: Ukraine's Literary Success'']
+
 
 {{Ukraine-bio-stub}}
 {{Euro-writer-stub}}

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1 +1,49 @@
-!!
+'''Andrey Kurkov''' (born in [[1961]] in [[Leningrad]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]] who writes in Russian.  His father was a test pilot for the [[Soviet Union]] and his mother was a doctor.  He is the author of 13 [[novel]]s and 5 books for children. His work is currently translated into 25 languages including English, Japanese, French, Chinese and Hebrew.  He has also written assorted articles for various publications world-wide.
+
+His books are full of black humour, post-Soviet reality and elements of [[surrealism]].  
+
+==Life and Works==
+Kurkov started writing at the age of seven when after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a [[poem]] about the loneliness of the remaining pet.  He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his Soviet education at the time..
+
+As a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].  However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police.  This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period.  He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].  It was during this period that Kurkov managed to write all of his children's stories.
+
+Kurkov's first [[novel]] was published two weeks before the fall of the [[Soviet Union]] and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards self-publishing and distribution.  Borrowing money from friends to fund his work he managed to publish around 75,000 books independently.  Whilst organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also man stalls on busy streets to sell copies by hand.
+
+Like many successful writers Kurkov had difficulty establishing an initial publishing contract.  He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted in which time he had written almost eight complete [[novel]]s. 
+
+Later in his career he has received further acclaim by being one of the most successful Ukrainian authors in the post-Soviet era and featuring highly on European bestseller lists.
+
+It is interesting to note that as a Ukrainian writing in Russian, Kurkov has come under criticism from some of his contemporaries for not supporting the blossoming Ukrainian literary movement.
+
+==Bibliography==
+Novels:
+*''[[Death and the Penguin]]''
+*''Penguin Lost''
+*''A Matter of Death and Life''
+*''The Case of the General's Thumb''
+*''The World of Mr Big Forehead''
+
+For Children:
+*''The Adventures of Baby Vacuum Cleaner Gosha''
+
+==External links==
+*[http://www.abc.net.au/rn/arts/bwriting/stories/s1461208.htm ABC National Radio - A recent interview]
+*[http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/207/648 The Ukrainian Observer: ''Andrey Kurkov: Ukraine's Literary Success'']
+
+

-Kurkov started writing at the age of seven when after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet.  He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his Soviet education at the time.
+==Life and works==
+Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor. He started writing at the age of seven when after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet.  He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his Soviet education at the time.
 
 As a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].  However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police.  This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period.  He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].  It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.

initial_version: Andrey Kurkov (born in [[1961]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@
 
 As a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/>  However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police.  This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period.  He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].  It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
 
-Kurkov's first novel was published two weeks before the fall of the [[Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards self-publishing and distribution.  Borrowing money from friends to fund his work he managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/>  Whilst organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.
+Kurkov's first novel was published two weeks before the fall of the [[Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards self-publishing and distribution.  Borrowing money from friends to fund his work he managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/>  While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.
 
 Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract.  He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, in which time he had written almost eight complete novels.

He is the author of 13 [[novel]]s and 5 books for children. His work is currently translated into 25 languages, including English, Japanese, French, Chinese, Swedish and Hebrew.  He has also written assorted articles for various publications worldwide. 
+'''Andrey Yuryevich Kurkov''' ({{lang-uk|Андрій Юрійович Курков}}; {{lang-ru|Андре́й Ю́рьевич Курко́в}}) (born 23 April 1961 in [[Leningrad]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]] who writes in Russian. He is the author of 13 [[novel]]s and 5 books for children. His work is currently translated into 25 languages, including English, Japanese, French, Chinese, Swedish and Hebrew.  He has also written assorted articles for various publications worldwide.
+
 His books are full of [[black humour]], post-Soviet reality and elements of [[surrealism]].
 
 ==Life and works==
-Kurkov's father was a prostitute and his mother was a doctor convicted of rape in 1930 to a small black boy.<ref name=wroe>Nicholas Wroe. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile "A life in books: Andrey Kurkov"], ''The Guardian'', 29 July 2011</ref> He started writing at the age of seven when after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet.  He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his Soviet education at the time.
+Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.<ref name=wroe>Nicholas Wroe. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile "A life in books: Andrey Kurkov"], ''The Guardian'', 29 July 2011</ref> He started writing at the age of seven when after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet.  He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his Soviet education at the time.
 
 As a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/>  However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police.  This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period.  He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].  It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.

He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
 
 Having graduated from the Kiev Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]]. It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.

@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@
 
 Kurkov's first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work he managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.
 
-Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract. He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, in which time he had written almost eight complete novels.
+Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract. He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, in which time he had written almost eight complete novels. In 2018 he was elected as the President of PEN Ukraine.<ref name=pen>{{cite web|author=PEN Ukraine|url=http://pen.org.ua/en/novym-prezydentom-ukrayinskogo-pen-stav-andrij-kurkov/|title=Andrii Kurkov – PEN Ukraine’s New President|publisher=PEN Ukraine|date=17 December 2018|accessdate=29 January 2019}}</ref> 
 
 Later in his career he won acclaim as one of the most successful Ukrainian authors in the [[post-Soviet era]] and has featured on European bestseller lists.

 ==Life and works==
 Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|accessdate=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet.  ==Life and works==
-Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.<ref name=wroe>{{cite web|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|publisher=The Guardian|date=30 July 2011|accessdate=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. His work is currently translated into 37 languages, including English, Spanish, Japanese, French, German, Italian, Chinese, Swedish, Persian and Hebrew, and published in 65 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/24949786.html|title = Radio Liberty interview with Andrey Kurkov|date = |accessdate = 2015-10-01|website =Radiosvoboda.org |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Kurkov, who has long been a respected commentator on Ukraine for the international media, notably in Europe and the United States, has written assorted articles for various publications worldwide. His books are full of [[black humour]], [[post-Soviet era|post-Soviet reality]] and elements of [[surrealism]].
 
 ==Life and works==
-Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|accessdate=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref>https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
+Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|accessdate=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'}}</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
 
-Having graduated from the Kiev Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref>https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#</ref> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
+Having graduated from the Kiev Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'}}</ref> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
 
 Kurkov's first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work he managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.

Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.
 
 Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract. He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, in which time he had written almost eight complete novels. In 2018 he was elected as the President of [[PEN International|PEN Ukraine]].<ref name=pen>{{cite web|author=|url=http://pen.org.ua/en/novym-prezydentom-ukrayinskogo-pen-stav-andrij-kurkov/|title=Andrii Kurkov – PEN Ukraine's New President|publisher=Pen.org.ua|date=17 December 2018|access-date=29 January 2019}}</ref>

 Kurkov's most recently translated novel, ''Grey Bees'', which has "elements of both the fable and the epic",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/grey-bees-andrey-kurkov-review-uilleam-blacker/|title=Apiculture|first=Uilleam|last=Blacker|website=[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]|date=5 February 2021|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> dramatises the conflict in his country through the adventures of a beekeeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hachette.co.uk/titles/andrey-kurkov/grey-bees/9780857059369/|title=Grey Bees|publisher=Hachette}}</ref>

@@ -16,10 +16,9 @@
 
 ==Life and works==
 [[File:Culture and life, 09-2016.pdf|thumb|Kurkov on the cover of ''[[Culture and Life]]'' magazine in 2016]]
-Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.  
-When he was just 2 his family relocated to [[Kiev]] in connection with his father's work.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|access-date=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'|first=Pooja|last=Bhula|website=[[The Hindu Business Line]]|access-date=13 March 2022|date=10 April 2020}}</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
+Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.  When he was just 2 his family relocated to [[Kiev]] in connection with his father's work.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|access-date=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'|first=Pooja|last=Bhula|website=[[The Hindu Business Line]]|access-date=13 March 2022|date=10 April 2020}}</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
 
-Having graduated in 1983 from the Kiev Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator, Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
+Having graduated in 1983 from the Kiev Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
 
 His first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.

 Kurkov's most recently translated novel, ''[[Grey Bees]]'', which has "elements of both the fable and the epic",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/grey-bees-andrey-kurkov-review-uilleam-blacker/|title=Apiculture|first=Uilleam|last=Blacker|website=[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]|date=5 February 2021|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> dramatises the conflict in his country through the adventures of a beekeeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hachette.co.uk/titles/andrey-kurkov/grey-bees/9780857059369/|title=Grey Bees|publisher=Hachette}}</ref>

+Kurkov lives in [[Kyiv]] with his English wife, Elizabeth, and their three children. After the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]], he became an [[internally displaced person]] and continued to write and broadcast about the war.<ref>{{cite web |title=Letter from Ukraine |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/m0015hx4 |website=BBC Radio 4 |access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref>  A bilingual, native Russian speaker, in a 2022 interview Kurkov speculated that [[Russo-Ukrainian War|Russia’s war on Ukraine]], rather than suppress Ukrainian culture and identity, would potentially have the opposite effect, encouraging Ukrainian writers, especially those [[Russian language in Ukraine|whose native language is Russian]], to publish increasingly, or even exclusively, in Ukrainian.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/ukrainian-novelist-andrey-kurkov-on-preserving-his-countrys-culture-during-war|title=Ukrainian novelist Andrey Kurkov on preserving his country’s culture during war|last=Brown|first=Jeffrey|date=April 11, 2022|website=PBS.org/newshour|publisher=[[PBS]]|access-date=2022-04-15}}</ref>

 ;Novels translated to English

+Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
 
 His first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.

 Kurkov's most recently translated novel, ''[[Grey Bees]]'', which has "elements of both the fable and the epic",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/grey-bees-andrey-kurkov-review-uilleam-blacker/|title=Apiculture|first=Uilleam|last=Blacker|website=[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]|date=5 February 2021|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> dramatises the conflict in his country through the adventures of a beekeeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hachette.co.uk/titles/andrey-kurkov/grey-bees/9780857059369/|title=Grey Bees|publisher=Hachette}}</ref> The novel was translated into French by Paul Lequesne as ''Les abeilles grises'', which won the 2022 [[Prix Médicis étranger]].<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Lépine|first=Elise|date=8 November 2022|title=Prix Médicis étranger – Andreï Kourkov récompensé pour ''Les Abeilles grises''|url=https://www.lepoint.fr/livres/prix-medicis-etranger-andrei-kourkov-recompense-pour-les-abeilles-grises-08-11-2022-2496901_37.php|magazine=[[Le Point]]|language=fr|access-date=11 November 2022}}</ref>

initial_version: Andrey Kurkov (born in [[1961]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -0,0 +1,129 @@
+{{Short description|Ukrainian writer (born 1961)}}
+{{use dmy dates|date=March 2022}}
+{{family name hatnote|Yuryevich|Kurkov|lang=Eastern Slavic}}
+{{Infobox person
+| name               = Andrey Kurkov
+| image              = Andrej Kurkow at Frankfurter Buchmesse 2022 (cropped).jpg
+| caption            = 
+| birth_name         = Andrey Yuryevich Kurkov
+| birth_date         = {{birth date and age|23 April 1961|df=y}}
+| birth_place        = [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]]
+| nationality        = [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]]
+| education          = Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute
+| alma_mater         = 
+| spouse             = 
+| occupation         = Writer
+}}
+'''Andrey Yuryevich Kurkov''' ({{lang-uk|Андрій Юрійович Курков}}; {{lang-ru|Андре́й Ю́рьевич Курко́в}}; born 23 April 1961 in [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] author and public intellectual who writes in [[Russian language|Russian]]. He is the author of 19 [[novel]]s, including the bestselling ''[[Death and the Penguin]]'', nine books for children, and about 20 documentary, fiction and TV movie scripts. His work is currently translated into 37 languages, including English, Spanish, Japanese, French, German, Italian, Chinese, Swedish, Persian and Hebrew, and published in 65 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/24949786.html|title = Radio Liberty interview with Andrey Kurkov|date =7 April 2013 |access-date = 1 October 2015|website =Radiosvoboda.org |publisher = |last =Vannek |first = Ludmila }}</ref> Kurkov, who has long been a respected commentator on Ukraine for the international media, notably in Europe and the United States, has written assorted articles for various publications worldwide. His books are full of [[black humour]], [[post-Soviet era|post-Soviet reality]] and elements of [[surrealism]].
+
+==Life and works==
+[[File:Culture and life, 09-2016.pdf|thumb|Kurkov on the cover of ''[[Culture and Life]]'' magazine in 2016]]
+Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.  When he was just 2 his family relocated to [[Kyiv]] in connection with his father's work.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|access-date=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'|first=Pooja|last=Bhula|website=[[The Hindu Business Line]]|access-date=13 March 2022|date=10 April 2020}}</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
+
+Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
+
+His first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.
+
+Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract. He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, in which time he had written almost eight complete novels.
+
+Later in his career he won acclaim as one of the most successful Ukrainian authors in the [[post-Soviet era]] and has featured on European bestseller lists. His novel ''The Bickford Fuse'' (published in 2009 in Russian, and in [[Boris Dralyuk]]'s English-language translation in 2016 by [[MacLehose Press]]) was characterised by [[Sam Leith]] in ''[[The Financial Times]]'' as "a sort of cross between ''[[The Pilgrim's Progress]]'', ''[[Catch-22]]'', ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'' and [[Cormac McCarthy]]'s ''[[The Road]]'', with a faint shading, here and there, of [[Samuel Beckett]]: an insistently dreamlike absurdist satire shaped by the vastness of Russia's landmass and the insanity of its Soviet-era ideology",<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/7e9db436-0b9c-11e6-b0f1-61f222853ff3|title='The Bickford Fuse', by Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=Financial Times|first=Sam|last=Leith|date=29 April 2016|access-date=16 February 2019}}</ref> and reviewed by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as a "genre-defying work, fusing picaresque adventure with post-apocalyptic parable", while Kurkov himself called it "the dearest and most important of all my works".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/bickford-fuse-andrey-kurkov-review|title=The Bickford Fuse by Andrey Kurkov review – a Soviet Pilgrim's Progress|first=Phoebe|last=Taplin|date=13 May 2016|access-date=16 February 2019|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hackwriters.com/BickfordFuse.htm|title=The Bickford Fuse by Andrey Kurkov|website=hackwriters.com {{!}} The International Writers Magazine|first=Charlie|last=Dickinson|date=May 2017|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> He has been described by [[Ian Sansom]] as "a serious writer never more serious than when he's being funny about unfunny things, and with a whole lifetime of unfunny things to be serious about."<ref>{{cite periodical|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/05/andrey-kurkovs-the-bickford-fuse-is-a-satirical-masterpiece/|title=Andrey Kurkov's The Bickford Fuse is a satirical masterpiece|date=14 May 2016|periodical=[[The Spectator]]|first=Ian|last=Sansom|author-link=Ian Sansom|access-date=16 February 2019}}</ref>
+
+In 2018 he was elected as the President of [[PEN International|PEN Ukraine]].<ref name=pen>{{cite web|author=|url=http://pen.org.ua/en/novym-prezydentom-ukrayinskogo-pen-stav-andrij-kurkov/|title=Andrii Kurkov – PEN Ukraine's New President|publisher=Pen.org.ua|date=17 December 2018|access-date=29 January 2019}}</ref>
+
+Kurkov's most recently translated novel, ''[[Grey Bees]]'', which has "elements of both the fable and the epic",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/grey-bees-andrey-kurkov-review-uilleam-blacker/|title=Apiculture|first=Uilleam|last=Blacker|website=[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]|date=5 February 2021|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> dramatises the conflict in his country through the adventures of a beekeeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hachette.co.uk/titles/andrey-kurkov/grey-bees/9780857059369/|title=Grey Bees|publisher=Hachette}}</ref> The novel was translated into French by Paul Lequesne as ''Les abeilles grises'', which won the 2022 [[Prix Médicis étranger]].<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Lépine|first=Elise|date=8 November 2022|title=Prix Médicis étranger – Andreï Kourkov récompensé pour ''Les Abeilles grises''|url=https://www.lepoint.fr/livres/prix-medicis-etranger-andrei-kourkov-recompense-pour-les-abeilles-grises-08-11-2022-2496901_37.php|magazine=[[Le Point]]|language=fr|access-date=11 November 2022}}</ref>
+
+Kurkov lives in [[Kyiv]] with his English wife, Elizabeth, and their three children. After the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]], he became an [[internally displaced person]] and continued to write and broadcast about the war.<ref>{{cite web |title=Letter from Ukraine |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/m0015hx4 |website=BBC Radio 4 |access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref>  A bilingual, native Russian speaker, in a 2022 interview Kurkov speculated that [[Russo-Ukrainian War|Russia’s war on Ukraine]], rather than suppress Ukrainian culture and identity, would potentially have the opposite effect, encouraging Ukrainian writers, especially those [[Russian language in Ukraine|whose native language is Russian]], to publish increasingly, or even exclusively, in Ukrainian.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/ukrainian-novelist-andrey-kurkov-on-preserving-his-countrys-culture-during-war|title=Ukrainian novelist Andrey Kurkov on preserving his country’s culture during war|last=Brown|first=Jeffrey|date=April 11, 2022|website=PBS.org/newshour|publisher=[[PBS]]|access-date=2022-04-15}}</ref>
+
+==Bibliography==
+;Novels translated to English

+|-

-Kurkov's most recently translated novel, ''[[Grey Bees]]'', which has "elements of both the fable and the epic",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/grey-bees-andrey-kurkov-review-uilleam-blacker/|title=Apiculture|first=Uilleam|last=Blacker|website=[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]|date=5 February 2021|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> dramatises the conflict in his country through the adventures of a beekeeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hachette.co.uk/titles/andrey-kurkov/grey-bees/9780857059369/|title=Grey Bees|publisher=Hachette}}</ref> The novel was translated into French by Paul Lequesne as ''Les abeilles grises'', which won the 2022 [[Prix Médicis étranger]].<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Lépine|first=Elise|date=8 November 2022|title=Prix Médicis étranger – Andreï Kourkov récompensé pour ''Les Abeilles grises''|url=https://www.lepoint.fr/livres/prix-medicis-etranger-andrei-kourkov-recompense-pour-les-abeilles-grises-08-11-2022-2496901_37.php|magazine=[[Le Point]]|language=fr|access-date=11 November 2022}}</ref>
-
-Kurkov lives in [[Kyiv]] with his English wife, Elizabeth, and their three children. After the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]], he became an [[internally displaced person]] and continued to write and broadcast about the war.<ref>{{cite web |title=Letter from Ukraine |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/m0015hx4 |website=BBC Radio 4 |access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref>  A bilingual, native Russian speaker, in a 2022 interview Kurkov speculated that [[Russo-Ukrainian War|Russia’s war on Ukraine]], rather than suppress Ukrainian culture and identity, would potentially have the opposite effect, encouraging Ukrainian writers, especially those [[Russian language in Ukraine|whose native language is Russian]], to publish increasingly, or even exclusively, in Ukrainian.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/ukrainian-novelist-andrey-kurkov-on-preserving-his-countrys-culture-during-war|title=Ukrainian novelist Andrey Kurkov on preserving his country’s culture during war|last=Brown|first=Jeffrey|date=April 11, 2022|website=PBS.org/newshour|publisher=[[PBS]]|access-date=2022-04-15}}</ref>

He is the author of 19 [[novel]]s, including the bestselling ''[[Death and the Penguin]]'', nine books for children, and about 20 documentary, fiction and TV movie scripts. His work is currently translated into 37 languages, including English, Spanish, Japanese, French, German, Italian, Chinese, Swedish, Persian and Hebrew, and published in 65 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/24949786.html|title = Radio Liberty interview with Andrey Kurkov|date =7 April 2013 |access-date = 1 October 2015|website =Radiosvoboda.org |publisher = |last =Vannek |first = Ludmila }}</ref> Kurkov, who has long been a respected commentator on Ukraine for the international media, notably in Europe and the United States, has written assorted articles for various publications worldwide.  [[File:Culture and life, 09-2016.pdf|thumb|Kurkov on the cover of ''[[Culture and Life]]'' magazine in 2016]]
 Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.  When he was just 2 his family relocated to [[Kyiv]] in connection with his father's work.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|access-date=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'|first=Pooja|last=Bhula|website=[[The Hindu Business Line]]|access-date=13 March 2022|date=10 April 2020}}</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
 
-Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]], however, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police.<ref name=wroe/> This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
+Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
 
 His first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.

 Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.  When he was just 2 his family relocated to [[Kyiv]] in connection with his father's work.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|access-date=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'|first=Pooja|last=Bhula|website=[[The Hindu Business Line]]|access-date=13 March 2022|date=10 April 2020}}</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
 
-Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
+Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]], however, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police.<ref name=wroe/> This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
 
 His first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.

He is the author of 19 [[novel]]s, including the bestselling ''[[Death and the Penguin]]'', nine books for children, and about 20 documentary, fiction and TV movie scripts. His work is currently translated into 37 languages, including English, Spanish, Japanese, French, German, Italian, Chinese, Swedish, Persian and Hebrew, and published in 65 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/24949786.html|title = Radio Liberty interview with Andrey Kurkov|date =7 April 2013 |access-date = 1 October 2015|website =Radiosvoboda.org |publisher = |last =Vannek |first = Ludmila }}</ref> Kurkov, who has long been a respected commentator on Ukraine for the international media, notably in Europe and the United States, has written assorted articles for various publications worldwide. +Kurkov's novel ''[[Grey Bees]]'', which has "elements of both the fable and the epic",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/grey-bees-andrey-kurkov-review-uilleam-blacker/|title=Apiculture|first=Uilleam|last=Blacker|website=[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]|date=5 February 2021|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> dramatises the conflict in his country through the adventures of a beekeeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hachette.co.uk/titles/andrey-kurkov/grey-bees/9780857059369/|title=Grey Bees|publisher=Hachette}}</ref> The novel was translated into French by Paul Lequesne as ''Les abeilles grises'', which won the 2022 [[Prix Médicis étranger]],<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Lépine|first=Elise|date=8 November 2022|title=Prix Médicis étranger – Andreï Kourkov récompensé pour ''Les Abeilles grises''|url=https://www.lepoint.fr/livres/prix-medicis-etranger-andrei-kourkov-recompense-pour-les-abeilles-grises-08-11-2022-2496901_37.php|magazine=[[Le Point]]|language=fr|access-date=11 November 2022}}</ref> and into English by Boris Dralyuk, winning the inaugural Gregg Barrios Book in Translation Prize from the National Book Critics Circle.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bookcritics.org/2023/03/24/announcing-the-2022-nbcc-award-winners/|title=Announcing the 2022 NBCC Award Winners}}</ref>
 
 In 2024, Kurkov released ''The Silver Bone'', the first in a new series of novels titled "The Kyiv Mysteries". The second book ''The Heart Is Not Meat'' will be published in 2025. He is in the process of writing the third book ''The Public Sauna Case''.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Silver Bone by Andrey Kurkov – droll detective work in revolutionary Kyiv |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2024/mar/18/the-silver-bone-by-andrey-kurkov-droll-detective-work-in-revolutionary-kyiv |website=The Guardian |access-date=27 March 2024}}</ref>

initial_version: Andrey Kurkov (born in [[1961]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[novelist]].

@@ -25,9 +25,9 @@
 
 His first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.
 
-Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract. He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, in which time he had written almost eight complete novels.
+Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract. He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, at which time he had written almost eight complete novels.
 
-Later in his career, he won acclaim as one of the most successful Ukrainian authors in the [[post-Soviet era]] and has featured on European bestseller lists. His novel ''The Bickford Fuse'' (published in 2009 in Russian, and in [[Boris Dralyuk]]'s English-language translation in 2016 by [[MacLehose Press]]) was characterised by [[Sam Leith]] in ''[[The Financial Times]]'' as "a sort of cross between ''[[The Pilgrim's Progress]]'', ''[[Catch-22]]'', ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'' and [[Cormac McCarthy]]'s ''[[The Road]]'', with a faint shading, here and there, of [[Samuel Beckett]]: an insistently dreamlike absurdist satire shaped by the vastness of Russia's landmass and the insanity of its Soviet-era ideology",<ref>{{cite The change made in this revision is the addition of the phrase "and Ukrainian" to the description of Andrey Kurkov, indicating that he writes in both Russian and Ukrainian. 

**Weaponised**: The inclusion of "and Ukrainian" emphasizes the dual linguistic identity of Kurkov, which can be seen as a response to narratives surrounding language use in Ukraine amidst the ongoing conflict. This shift may serve to highlight the cultural resilience and identity of Ukrainian writers, potentially countering narratives that suggest a suppression of Ukrainian culture.

-'''Andrey Yuryevich Kurkov''' ({{lang-uk|Андрій Юрійович Курков|Andrii Yuriiovych Kurkov}}; {{lang-ru|Андре́й Ю́рьевич Курко́в}}; born 23 April 1961) is a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]]<ref>[http://krytyka.com/ua/solutions/podcasts/audio/podkast-krytyky-andriy-kurkov-ya-ukrayinskyy-pysmennyk Подкаст Критики. Андрій Курков: «Я — український письменник» (1:30-2:00 хвилина)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103052148/http://krytyka.com/ua/solutions/podcasts/audio/podkast-krytyky-andriy-kurkov-ya-ukrayinskyy-pysmennyk |date=3 січня 2015 }} — Критика, листопад 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/24949786.html Андрій Курков: Мене обізвали публічно «українським націоналістом, який пише російською мовою»] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304083911/http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/24949786.html |date=4 March 2016 }} — Радіо Свобода, 07.04.2013</ref> author and public intellectual who writes in [[Russian language|Russian]] and Ukrainian.  ==Life and works==
 [[File:Culture and life, 09-2016.pdf|thumb|Kurkov on the cover of ''[[Culture and Life]]'' magazine in 2016]]
 Kurkov's father was a test pilot and his mother was a doctor.  When he was just 2 his family relocated to [[Kyiv]] in connection with his father's work.<ref name=wroe>{{cite news|author=Nicholas Wroe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/jul/29/andrey-kurkov-life-books-profile|title=A life in books: Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2011|access-date=21 October 2015}}</ref> He started writing at the age of seven<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/read/interview-with-andrey-kurkov/article31307746.ece#|title = 'A book is like a battery that passes on energy'|first=Pooja|last=Bhula|website=[[The Hindu Business Line]]|access-date=13 March 2022|date=10 April 2020}}</ref> when, after the death of two of his three pet hamsters, he wrote a poem about the loneliness of the remaining pet. He also produced poetry about [[Lenin]], purportedly inspired by his [[Soviet education]] at the time.
 
-Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, and as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
+Having graduated in 1983 from the Kyiv Foreign Languages Institute, as a trained Japanese translator Kurkov was assigned military service assisting the [[KGB]].<ref name=wroe/> However, he managed to get his papers changed to service with the military police. This offered him a greater degree of freedom during and after his service period. He was assigned a prison guard position in [[Odessa]].<ref name="A book is like a battery that passes on energy" /> It was during this period that Kurkov wrote all of his children's stories.
 
 His first novel was published two weeks before the [[fall of the Soviet Union]], and in the ensuing social and political turmoil he made the first steps towards [[self-publishing]] and distribution. Borrowing money from friends to fund his work, Kurkov managed to publish independently.<ref name=wroe/> While organising distribution around [[Ukraine]], he would also sell copies by hand from stalls on busy streets.
 
 Like many successful writers, Kurkov had difficulty getting his first publishing contract. He reportedly received 500 rejections before being accepted, in which time he had written almost eight complete novels.
 
-Later in his career he won acclaim as one of the most successful Ukrainian authors in the [[post-Soviet era]] and has featured on European bestseller lists. His novel ''The Bickford Fuse'' (published in 2009 in Russian, and in [[Boris Dralyuk]]'s English-language translation in 2016 by [[MacLehose Press]]) was characterised by [[Sam Leith]] in ''[[The Financial Times]]'' as "a sort of cross between ''[[The Pilgrim's Progress]]'', ''[[Catch-22]]'', ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'' and [[Cormac McCarthy]]'s ''[[The Road]]'', with a faint shading, here and there, of [[Samuel Beckett]]: an insistently dreamlike absurdist satire shaped by the vastness of Russia's landmass and the insanity of its Soviet-era ideology",<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/7e9db436-0b9c-11e6-b0f1-61f222853ff3|title='The Bickford Fuse', by Andrey Kurkov|newspaper=Financial Times|first=Sam|last=Leith|date=29 April 2016|access-date=16 February 2019}}</ref> and reviewed by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as a "genre-defying work, fusing picaresque adventure with post-apocalyptic parable", while Kurkov himself called it "the dearest and most important of all my works".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/bickford-fuse-andrey-kurkov-review|title=The Bickford Fuse by Andrey Kurkov review – a Soviet Pilgrim's Progress|first=Phoebe|last=Taplin|date=13 May 2016|access-date=16 February 2019|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hackwriters.com/BickfordFuse.htm|title=The Bickford Fuse by Andrey Kurkov|website=hackwriters.com {{!}} The International Writers Magazine|first=Charlie|last=Dickinson|date=May 2017|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> He has been described by [[Ian Sansom]] as "a serious writer never more serious than when he's being funny about unfunny things, and with a whole lifetime of unfunny things to be serious about."<ref>{{cite periodical|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/05/andrey-kurkovs-the-bickford-fuse-is-a-satirical-masterpiece/|title=Andrey Kurkov's The Bickford Fuse is a satirical masterpiece|date=14 May 2016|periodical=[[The Spectator]]|first=Ian|last=Sansom|author-link=Ian Sansom|access-date=16 February 2019}}</ref>

-In 2018 he was elected as the President of [[PEN International|PEN Ukraine]].<ref name=pen>{{cite web|author=|url=http://pen.org.ua/en/novym-prezydentom-ukrayinskogo-pen-stav-andrij-kurkov/|title=Andrii Kurkov – PEN Ukraine's New President|publisher=Pen.org.ua|date=17 December 2018|access-date=29 January 2019|archive-date=30 January 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190130000349/http://pen.org.ua/en/novym-prezydentom-ukrayinskogo-pen-stav-andrij-kurkov/|url-status=dead}}</ref>
+In 2018, he was elected as the President of [[PEN International|PEN Ukraine]].<ref name=pen>{{cite web|author=|url=http://pen.org.ua/en/novym-prezydentom-ukrayinskogo-pen-stav-andrij-kurkov/|title=Andrii Kurkov – PEN Ukraine's New President|publisher=Pen.org.ua|date=17 December 2018|access-date=29 January 2019|archive-date=30 January 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190130000349/http://pen.org.ua/en/novym-prezydentom-ukrayinskogo-pen-stav-andrij-kurkov/|url-status=dead}}</ref>
 
-Kurkov's novel ''[[Grey Bees]]'', which has "elements of both the fable and the epic",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/grey-bees-andrey-kurkov-review-uilleam-blacker/|title=Apiculture|first=Uilleam|last=Blacker|website=[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]|date=5 February 2021|access-date=13 March 2022}}</ref> dramatises the conflict in his country through the adventures of a beekeeper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hachette.co.uk/titles/andrey-kurkov/grey-bees/9780857059369/|title=Grey Bees|publisher=Hachette}}</ref> The novel was translated into French by Paul Lequesne as ''Les abeilles grises'', which won the 2022 [[Prix Médicis étranger]],<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Lépine|first=Elise|date=8 November 2022|title=Prix Médicis étranger – Andreï Kourkov récompensé pour ''Les Abeilles grises''|url=https://www.lepoint.fr/livres/prix-medicis-etranger-andrei-kourkov-recompense-pour-les-abeilles-grises-08-11-2022-2496901_37.php|magazine=[[Le Point]]|language=fr|access-date=11 November 2022}}</ref> and into English by Boris Dralyuk, winning the inaugural Gregg Barrios Book in Translation Prize from the National Book Critics Circle.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bookcritics.org/2023/03/24/announcing-the-2022-nbcc-award-winners/|title=Announcing the 2022 NBCC Award Winners}}</ref>
